title: Thrupp, Oxfordshire
text:
Thrupp is a <a href="Hamlet%20%28place%29">hamlet</a> just north of <a href="Kidlington">Kidlington</a> in Oxfordshire. It is beside the <a href="Oxford%20Canal">Oxford Canal</a> and close to the <a href="River%20Cherwell">River Cherwell</a>.
History.
Before the <a href="Norman%20conquest%20of%20England">Norman conquest of England</a> in 1066 <a href="Stigand">Stigand</a>, <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a> held the <a href="manorialism">manor</a> of Thrupp. In 1070 Stigand was deposed and <a href="William%20I%20of%20England">William the Conqueror</a> confiscated his lands. William granted Thrupp to <a href="Roger%20d%27Ivry">Roger d'Ivry</a>, who sold it to <a href="Wadard">Wadard</a>, a <a href="knight">knight</a> in William's court. In 1086 Thrupp was such a small settlement that the <a href="Domesday%20Book">Domesday Book</a> did not record it as having any tenants. Thrupp has the remains of a 15th century cross carved from <a href="Cotswold%20stone">local Jurassic limestone</a>. The cross itself has been lost, but the base and rather weathered shaft survive. The present Manor Farm buildings date from the early part of the 17th century. As well as the farmhouse there are a <a href="granary">granary</a> and <a href="dovecote">dovecote</a> from the same period. The farm used to have a <a href="watermill">watermill</a> powered by the River Cherwell.
In 1788 the Oxford Canal was extended southwards from Northbrook Lock just north of <a href="Tackley">Tackley</a> towards <a href="Kidlington">Kidlington</a> and <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a>. It roughly parallels the River Cherwell until Thrupp, where it turns away from the river in a right-angle around Manor Farm to approach Oxford along the valley of the <a href="River%20Thames">River Thames</a> rather than that of the Cherwell. The canal company bought the manorial watermill, demolished most of it, and built a row of cottages beside the canal in its place. They used to be called Salt Row, and one historian suggests that they served as salt warehouses. In the 18th century Thrupp had two <a href="public%20house">public house</a>s: the Axe which is now the Boat Inn, and the Three Horseshoes which closed in 1924. In the 20th century the Britannia opened on the main Banbury Road. It has since been renamed the Jolly Boatman. Both the Boat Inn and the Jolly Boatman are now controlled by <a href="Greene%20King%20Brewery">Greene King Brewery</a>.
Thrupp has no <a href="Church%20of%20England%20parish%20church">Church of England parish church</a> of its own. In 1876 <a href="Woodstock%2C%20Oxfordshire">Woodstock</a> <a href="Baptist">Baptist</a> Church converted a house in Thrupp into a chapel. In 1953 the Baptists built a new church in nearby Kidlington, and in 1954 Thrupp chapel was consequently closed and sold. It has since been converted back into a house, but retains the external appearance of a chapel that it acquired in 1876. The 15th century cross, which may have originally stood on the main Banbury Road, now stands in front of the former chapel. At the end of the road through Thrupp is a <a href="drawbridge">drawbridge</a> across the canal. On the other side is a yard with three cottages with a common thatched roof. In 1989 <a href="BBC">BBC</a> Television filmed scenes for the <a href="Inspector%20Morse%20%28TV%20series%29">Inspector Morse</a> drama series episode "The Last Enemy" near the canal and the Boat Inn.
